Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Showers and thunderstorms will continue to soak the region overnight into Saturday morning with total rainfall amounts of 20 to 40 mm likely in many areas. A few locally higher rainfall amounts of 40 to 50 mm are possible. Poor driving conditions from low visibility in downpours are expected tonight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-21T14:51:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-21T07:25:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3294055302.2019

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Severe thunderstorms are possible tonight. A north to south line of thunderstorms extending from Southern Manitoba to North Dakota is moving east and may cross the border into Northwestern Ontario late this evening. This line of thunderstorms will then move east across the region through the overnight hours. The main threats are torrential rainfall, wind gusts up to 90 km/h, and loonie sized hail. Some of the thunderstorms may also contain frequent lightning. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.
Expires: 2019-09-21T16:07:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-21T04:08:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1993508247.2019
Area: Pikangikum - Poplar Hill - MacDowell

properties.Title: Tropical Cyclone Information Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: For Post-tropical Storm Humberto. The next information statement will be issued by 09:30 a.m. NDT. Post-Tropical storm Humberto now over the southwestern Grand Banks. Some rain bands reaching southeastern Newfoundland, with gale to storm force winds occurring over offshore waters. 1. Summary of basic information at 03:30 a.m. NDT. Location: Near 45.0 North 52.7 West. About 190 kilometres south of Cape Race. Maximum sustained winds: 100 kilometres per hour. Present movement: East-northeast at 39 kilometres per hour. Minimum central pressure: 981 millibars. 2. Public weather impacts and warnings summary. No significant effects are expected over land. a. Wind. No significant wind expected. b. Rainfall. Some outer rain bands from Humberto will continue to affect portions of the Avalon and Burin Peninsulas this morning. c. Surge/Waves. Swells of 3 to 5 metres will continue to affect southern Newfoundland this morning. Waves will break higher along some areas of the coastline, and dangerous rip currents are possible. 3. Marine weather impacts and warnings summary. Storm warnings are in effect for the Southern Grand Banks. Gale warnings are in effect for Laurentian Fan, Banquereau - southern half, Northeast Coast and East Coast of Newfoundland, Funk Island bank and the Northern Grand Banks. Gale to Storm Force winds are occurring over the southern Grand Banks this morning, with some lingering gales in the wake of Humberto continuing for a few more hours over southeastern Maritimes waters. Significant wave heights of 7 to 10 metres are forecast to the right of Humberto's track over offshore waters this morning. Forecaster(s): Borgel ### Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-09-21T22:59:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-21T05:39:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1910298240.2019
Area: Avalon Peninsula Southeast, Avalon Peninsula Southwest

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of very dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing damaging wind gusts, damaging hail and flooding rain. Thunderstorms continue to develop over North Dakota and southern Manitoba this evening ahead of a trough of low pressure now located over western Manitoba. These storms will develop into a squall line and track eastward across southern Manitoba this evening and into eastern Manitoba overnight. Heavy rainfall can be expected again with fairly widespread 50 to 100 mm of rain possible. Combined with the heavy rainfall this morning, significant flooding can be expected with the already over saturated ground. Large hail and wind gusts over 100 km/h along the squall line are also likely. Isolated tornadoes with any embedded supercells over the southern Red River Valley this evening cannot be ruled out. ### Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Heavy downpours are likely to cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-21T10:39:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-20T23:50:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1752414668.2019

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of very dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing damaging wind gusts, large hail and flooding rain. Thunderstorm activity will continue through the night over northern North Dakota and Minnesota. Some of these thunderstorms may move into southeastern Manitoba during the overnight hours and have the potential to bring torrential rain, strong winds, and intense lightning. ### Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Heavy downpours are likely to cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
